name: Meleagro (Copia di)
description: Plaster cast of a Roman copy in marble from the Protonant era from a Hellenistic original probably from Skopas from the mid-4th century BC .; the dog and the head are additions of the Roman copyist. The marble group is preserved in the Vatican Museums. The original remains the property of the Pighini family until 1770 when it was purchased by Clement XIV. Numerous casts are known in the main academies. The Bolognese cast, donated by Benedict XIV, is attributable to the mid-eighteenth century.

name: To measure of a window
description:
To measure of a window was produced during the 2020 period of quarantine, when many countries around the world went into lockdown to tackle the spread of Covid-19. It’s a personal response to crisis, uncertainty, and altered states of being.
"To measure of a window the body had to adapt to four angles." Massiel Leza

details.title: Provenance:
details.description: Accademia di Belle Arti di Bologna

details.title: Artist biography:
details.description: Massiel's work is the final result of a creative and very personal process, realized starting from self-knowledge, from a research as artistic as identity, from what she calls mental transit, that is the idealization of so many people she finds in herself. In her work she analyses the barrier of the body, which is defeated by the ability of different techniques to deal with themes such as social and gender identity, through transit or movement. Massiel Leza (Madrid 1990) after a law degree, she graduated in Photography, Painting and Visual Arts at the Department of Fine Arts of the University Distrital Francisco José de Caldas of Bogotá-Colombia, then she studied at the Department of DAMS of the University of Bologna through the Erasmus program, she is currently attending the Two-year Specialist Course of Visual Arts at the Academy of Fine Arts of Bologna.

name: Arianna (Copia di)
description: Plaster cast of a copy in Roman marble from the late-Hadrianic period or protoantonino from an original parchment of the 150th century. B.C. about. The Roman copy is kept at the Vatican Museums. The specimen dating from the mid-18th century presents the body of Cleopatra, also identified as Arianna, strongly reclined with respect to the original.

name: Cefiso (Copia di)
description: Marble mold from the original of Phidias (447-432 BC) for the western pediment of the Parthenon, preserved in the British Museum. The fame of the work, the peculiarity of the posture and the exceptional nature of the performance make it a fundamental work for learning design and the study of the figure in space, so much so as to have several specimens available for teaching.

description: Original marble

Plaster cast of a marble copy of the Roman imperial age probably from a bronze original of the school of Lysippus of the late 4th century - early 3rd century BC, preserved in the Louvre Museum. The cast, of excellent workmanship and with the support more ornate than the original, is ascribable at the beginning of the 18th century and mentioned among those sent to Bologna by General Marsili as a gift from his brother Monsignor Antonio.

name: Nike di Samotracia (Copia di)
creatorName: End of the 19th - beginning of the 20th century
description: Plaster cast from a marble original from 200 BC, from the island of Samothrace, preserved at the Louvre Museum. The cast is attributable between the late nineteenth and early twentieth century. There are many specimens present in Italian schools and academies, starting from the early twentieth century.

details.title: Date Created:
details.description: End of the 19th - beginning of the 20th century

description: Plaster cast from a Roman marble copy of a bronze original by Cresila from the second half of the 5th century BC, preserved in the Louvre Museum. The cast of Bologna, already in the Accademia in 1811, may have been cast before the statue left for Paris (September 1802), and arrive on the occasion of the establishment of the Royal Academy. The copy could also have been taken from the form made in Paris by the original, from which also the calder of Brera derives, complete however with the right arm of restoration. The absence of the arm is not sufficient to opt, in the absence of more precise documents, for one of the two hypotheses. In the inventory of 1803 a head of Pallas is also remembered.

details.title: Title:
details.description: Minerva o Pallade di Velletri (Copia di)

description: Plaster cast of a Roman marble copy from the middle of the 1st century BC from an original by Pergamum (241-197 BC) made for Attalus of Pergamon to commemorate the victory over the Gauls. The copy is kept at the Capitoline Museums.
Gesso preparatorio per il marmo del Monumento Caprara in Certosa a Bologna.
Copy from the original of the mid-6th century BC preserved in the Cyprus Museum

Plaster cast of a copy in Asian marble executed by a parchment atelier in the central decades of the 1st century BC (46-44 BC) from a bronze original of 230-220 BC of the Donario of Attalo I, preserved at the National Roman Museum. The statue depicts a Celtic prince who kills himself after killing his wife to veil them to end up a prisoner of the enemies. The Bolognese cast dating from the mid-18th century and already attested in Bologna in 1757 is probably a personal gift of the Prince of Piombino to the Academy or to the Pope, taken from the original statue.

description: Plaster casts of Roman marble copies of the Hadrianic age from bronze originals from the Hellenistic age from the eastern Mediterranean and preserved in the Capitoline Museums. The couple, also due to the very high quality attributable to the central decades of the eighteenth century, is already reported as present in Bologna in 1766, as indicated by the inventory concluded on April 30th of that year. The Bolognese specimens could also reasonably date back to the series produced in the famous Roman workshop.

description:
& nbsp was produced during the 2020 period of quarantine, when many countries around the world went into lockdown to tackle the spread of Covid-19. It’s a personal response to crisis, uncertainty, and altered states of being.
"& nbsp is a project born during these quarantine months. The title, "& nbsp", recalls the contemporary dimension, more precisely, in HTML language, is the code that creates an empty space within a line. Starting from this concept of forced empty space, mixing it with my daily life, I decided to create a project, created between my home and the passage places of these months, to create a very personal identikit during a very constricting phase of life. In this dimension of expectation and constraint, there is a very contemplative, repetitive and melancholic gaze of the passing of the days which are distinguished from the night only by the flow of the sun on the surfaces. This photo in particular represents the essence of the project, as the freest element that is found outside, enters the house and is forced to stay into a surface without a way to escape." Nicholas Pinna

description: Plaster cast from a work of the Augustan age, from a type from 450 BC probably depicting Augustus as a young Hermes from a type of 450 BC preserved at the Louvre Museum. The Bolognese specimen, ascribable to the mid-eighteenth century, arrived in Bologna at the behest of Benedict XIV, thanks to the amazed agreement with the Venetian nobleman, and would therefore derive from the controcalco realized on that occasion.

description: Plaster cast of a statue consisting of an original torso from a copy of the Discobolus of Mirone, restored by Pierre Etienne Monnot (1650-1733) to represent a gladiator standing on his left arm while falling to the ground, preserved in the Capitoline Museums. The cast, donated by Benedict XIV, is ascribable to the mid-eighteenth century and arrives in Bologna, together with the others indicated by the Pope, in 1757.

creatorName: Early decades of the Twentieth century
description: Plaster cast from the original marble of Praxiteles, depicting Hermes with Dionysus child (340, 330 BC) preserved in the Archaeological Museum of Olympia. The cast, ascribable to the early decades of the 20th century, depicts Herms resting with Dionio the child during the journey to lead him to the nymphs of Nissa.

details.title: Date Created:
details.description: Early decades of the Twentieth century

description: Plaster cast of a Roman copy of marble from originals probably from the pre-Saxon school, Rome Piazza del Quirinale. Reproduction of one of the heads of the figures in the Piazza del Quirinale, repeatedly rearranged together with the obelisk between the 18th and 19th centuries. In 1781 Pius VI granted authorizations to draw casts from both groups. In 1805 Giuseppe Bossi secured the casts of the heads for the Accademia di Brera. Thanks to the involvement of Pelagio Palagi, one of the two heads is already in Bologna before 1820.

description: Copy of the marble exhibited in the Medici Chapels in Florence

Plaster cast from an original depicting marble Aphrodite from the 2nd century BC preserved in the Louvre Museum. The original discovered in 1820 on the island of Milo, was bought on behalf of the French Ambassador to Constantinople in 1821 and offered to Louis XVIII. The work, found in two blocks, was reassembled and then rearranged in 1871. A cast was placed in the Berlin Academy since 1822 and there are numerous copies circulated in the academies and made with the use of pantograph. Even the cast of Bologna would be twentieth century.
Plaster casts

Plaster cast from an original in Greek marble, originally also identified as Zeno, from the 3rd century AD preserved at the Capitoline Museums in Rome. The original, discovered in 1701, comes from a Lanuvium villa. The Bolognese specimen, a gift from Benedict XIV, is attributable to the mid-eighteenth century.

creatorName: End of the 19th - beginning of the 20th century
description: Assyrian stone plaster cast from a male statue (last quarter of the 6th century BC) found at the temple of Golgoi in Cyprus by Luigi Palma di Casnola between 1866 and 1876, preserved at the Metropolitan Museum in New York. The cast, dating from the late nineteenth and early twentieth century, enters the Academy on February 22nd, 1904, donated by the Metropolitan Museum along with five others. These are copies of the most famous works recovered in Cyprus from General Palma di Cesnola, who in 1879, having become director, ceded his collection of Cypriot antiquities to the museum.

details.title: Date Created:
details.description: End of the 19th - beginning of the 20th century

creatorName: First decades of the nineteenth century
description: Plaster cast of a marble copy perhaps from the Augustan period from a bronze origin of Leochares placed in the Theater of Dionysus in Athens (328-326 c.C), preserved in the Vatican Museums. The specimen, of good workmanship, is ascribable to the first decades of the nineteenth century and is indicated in the guide of 1846, in the inventory of 1874 it is mentioned as a gift from C. Baruzzi.

details.description: First decades of the nineteenth century

description: Plaster cast from a marble original, depicting Laocoon with his sons fighting with snakes, by the sculptors Hagesandros, Polydoros and Athenadoros, mid-1st century BC, preserved at the Vatican Museums. A copy of the bust of Laocoonte has been present in the Academy since 1803. It could also be the specimen purchased by Pelagio Palagi together with other heads between 1797 and 1798

description: Plaster cast of a marble copy (90 BC) from a statue of Lysippos' school probably depicting a hero in combat. The marble copy is kept at the Louvre Museum. A gladiator is mentioned among the eight casts brought to Bologna by General Marsili. Another gladiator, identified as coming from the Borghese Collection, is indicated among the copies requested from Farsetti by Benedetto XIV. The Bolognese specimen would then be ascribable, at the latest, to the mid-eighteenth century.

description: Plaster cast from a marble original by the sculptors Hagesandros, Polydoros and Athenadoros, mid-1st century BC preserved in the Vatican Museums. There are two specimens of the Laocoon cast recorded as present in Bologna. The first sent by Marsili, the second donated by Benedict XIV in 1755. Only one has come down to us, in the version, more widespread among the copies, without the figures of the sons and with the right arm of Laocoon raised high, as in the restoration of Montorsoli. The Bolognese specimen, of good quality, but badly damaged before the recent restoration, of which it is difficult - in the current state of knowledge - to identify the exact origin, is however attributable to not later than the middle of the eighteenth century.

description: Plaster cast of a controversial original, an 18th century model on an ancient statue or an ancient statue with drapery retouched in the Baroque period, so as to make a convincing attribution impossible, preserved at the Capitoline Museums. The Bolognese cast, of good workmanship, a gift from Benedict XIV, is attributable to the mid-eighteenth century. In 1744, at the time of the entry of the original statue to the Capitoline Museum, casts are taken for the French Academy and for the Pontiff, this series could also date back to the example described here.

description: Plaster cast from a marble original by Apollonius of Athens from the mid-1st century BC, preserved in the Vatican Museums. The original depicts Filottete, the ailing hero abandoned in Lemnos waiting for the comrades to return. A cast of the torso would enter the Clementine Academy in 1727, thanks to the efforts of General Marsili. From at least 1811, according to the documents found so far, there would be a second cast: the first is included among the works owned by the city of Bologna, the second among the materials purchased by the Royal Academy from the moment of its establishment. Two copies are also documented at the end of the nineteenth century.

description:
Orange zone was produced during the 2020 period of quarantine, when many countries around the world went into lockdown to tackle the spread of Covid-19. It’s a personal response to crisis, uncertainty, and altered states of being.
"Looking out onto an inner courtyard is like having a homemade safari always available. Unpredictable human beings reveal their routines, their habits, and it is as if your gaze slowly tames them." Francesca Marra

description: Panels Premi Curlandesi

Plaster cast from the original Hadrianic marble preserved in the Capitoline Museums in Rome. The cast, belonging to the group donated by Benedict XIV, is ascribable to the mid-eighteenth century. In the Gallery of Statues there are two other depictions of Antinous, both mentioned together with the example of the capital in the inventory of 1766. One is the Antinoo al Bagno, also included in the papal gift; the other is the Antinoo del Belvedere, purchased by Marsili in 1713. The three specimens are mentioned in the inventory of 1803 and 1811.

description: Plaster cast of the portrait of Lucius Verus in Greek marble, 161 AD, examples of which are preserved in the Louvre Museum and the Ducal Palace in Mantua. A copy of the portrait of Lucio Vero is present in the Academy as early as 1803, in 1805 another copy arrives in Bologna, a gift from the Brera Academy from the workshop of the Roman formator Giuseppe Torrentei. To this copy, corresponding to the type described here, would refer to the design of Palagi, who could have copied it in his own Roman sudio before leaving for Bologna. The cast, of excellent workmanship, would therefore be attributable to the first few years of the nineteenth century.

description: The work wants to showcase the importance of personal priorities.

details.title: Provenance:
details.description: Accademia delle Belle Arti di Bologna

creatorName: Carol Graziani and Francesco De Conno
description:
Both as friends and artists, we want to think about how and why we communicate with each other.
We looked back at our shared experiences of this lockdown, reflecting on how important our continuous conversation has been in facing these hard times.
Locked up in our homes, through the glass of our windows, we see an alternative landscape made of the daily attempts to find human connections.
The words you hear are the ones we exchanged during the last two months.
What do you see when you scroll through your chats?
What do you feel when you hear your old texts read out loud?
Our phones, our windows onto each other, recorded our anxieties, our fears, the sense of being lost in a situation with which we couldn’t fully deal by our selves.
When we feel these emotions, when we feel in danger and we don’t know what to do, we reach out to others by tapping on their window searching in them what we can’t find in our selves.
A view on the Other is a view on the Self, on how, by developing our relationships, we cope with our traumas and we pick up the pieces to build our selves back in a new form.

details.title: Creator:
details.description: Carol Graziani and Francesco De Conno

name: La Morte ferma il Tempo e indica il Luogo
description:
I made an analysis on the words that make up the macro themes of Time and Place, I chose some words, I made a hierarchy and some patterns, and others I discarded. In the end, with the remaining words ( the ones that survived all the trials before which my analysis has placed them), I decided to write a prose, or rather two, one on Time and one on the Place, which then come together in one big writing.
From the sentences of the prose was born the blood pencil drawing of 150x200cm on paper. A Sensitive Lamb (a frequent subject of my drawings, a link between the living and the realm of the dead), becomes a Guiding Lamb, a map of Time and Place. The words are therefore related to each other in a Lamb scheme, useful to visualize what Time and Place mean in the Afterlife.

details.title: Title:
details.description: La Morte ferma il Tempo e indica il Luogo

details.title: Provenance:

description: Plaster cast of a marble copy of the 2nd-1st century BC from a bronze original of the 3rd century BC, preserved in the National Roman Museum. The specimen, ascribed with certainty in the mid-eighteenth century and of excellent workmanship, figures together with Arria and Peto, among the casts requested by Benedict XIV to Farsetti, who for his collection had to resort to a counter from the copy of Academy of France. However from the indications given by Senator Malvezzi to Cardinal Millo in 1757 we learn that, at the time of the delivery of the statues by Farsetti, the Aria and Peto group and the resting Ares were exchanged for eight busts.

description: Plaster cast of a Roman copy in marble of the original created by Mirone around 460 BC preserved in the Vatican Museums. The specimen, datable to the beginning of the XIXth century, reproduces the type preserved in the Vatican Museums and found in Tivoli in 1791. A second discus thrower "at rest" is remembered both in the inventory of 1811 and in that of 1874.
